Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2012 01:31PM ibcmets wrote: Pooka, Welcome.  I'm a stage IV inflammatory bc with bone mets patient from the start in 6/09.  I love my onc.  He's been very assertive, thorough and cautious with my treatment.  I had chemo for 8 months and have been on Zometa for 2.5 years every month.  After chemo, I was put on Femara for the last 2 years.  I've done very well and he scans me once every 6 months. You need to be very well monitored with stage IV.  It does sound like you have a good onc, maybe he needs to be just a bit more assertive & give you answers to why he recommends a certain treatment.  Femara & Zometa are still working after 2.5 years and I'm glad to check status every 6 months with Pet scans. Terri

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 12:04AM ibcmets wrote: Ladies, I'm all for private counseling for our kids going through this, although my 14 year old will not go.  The thing I worry about with counseling groups for kids is that we are all at different stages with our disease.  Some and many hopefully in the future stage IV survivors will live long lives.  I would hate that our kids would stress out more talking to kids that are currently dealing with end of life issues because it may give the impression that all the kids are going to deal with this sooner than they think. It's important to be honest with your kids; but if you are handling your treatments well and are stable; there is no need to scare them & stress them out more. I hope you understand what I'm trying to say. Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2011 01:04PM ibcmets wrote: I have been mostly on the same treatment plan as yours.  I have inflammatory bc with spinal bone mets.  I've done 8 months of TAC chemo (added adriamyacin with taxotere & cytoxin), monthly zometa for the bones and daily Femara after chemo was completed.  6/09 diagnosis. Did bi-lateral mastectomy after 1 year being stable.  Doing reconsruction now.  I'm hoping I don't have to do radiation.  Will go on Xgeva instead of Zometa as soon as my onc office gets it approved.  It's a shot instead of an infusion. I've handled chemo well.  I did take sublimininal B12 tablets and melatonin to help me sleep.  I also take glucosamine & chondrotin for joint pain & daily D3 & calcium.  I had some joint pain for about 6 months on Femara, than my body got used to it and I don't have it anymore.  Walking through the stiffness helped as you may feel stiff in the morning and have a hard time moving in the morning.  I had to take Femara at night as it made me feel  queesy taking it in the morning. Best to you on your treatment. Terri

Posts.Content: May 16, 2011 03:21PM ibcmets wrote: Cafelovr:   I love your take on this. New Reality:  I have aggressive inflammatory with spinal bone mets.  I thought as stage IV; I had skipped the surgery.  My onc recommended the surgery after I had been stable for 1 1/2 years after chemo.  My pathology report under BMX reported micro cancer still found in breast that was too small to show up on scans, so I'm glad I did it.  I'm on Femara & Lupron and monthly Zometa for bone mets.   I feel that even at stage IV, I may have prolonged my life by getting rid of the primary cancer.  If I had left it there, I feel like I would have had a reoccurrence a lot sooner than having the surgery done. We are here to support whatever decision you make.  In the past, stage IV surgery was not recommended.  Now, new research is showing some positive results in having the surgery. Terri

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2014 12:42PM ibcmets wrote: I'm 5 years out with stage IV bc with bone mets. I've been on Zometa (infusion instead of shot), basically same type of drug for bone mets. ONJ is always a concern on a biophasphonate. It has worked wonders for me and I have no ONJ with it. The anti-hormonals will most likely cause some joint stiffness & some pain, but work well to keep your friend stable so she won't have to go on chemo right away. I was stable for 4 years on Femera and there are a few others I can try before I have to go back onto chemo. I was only on chemo due to having inflammatory bc which is a more aggressive cancer. Thanks for looking out for your friend. Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 11:56PM - edited Mar 29, 2011 11:57PM by ibcmets Kathy, My HR benefits state that normal checkups are 100% covered while treatments for any diseases (such as cancer) may only pay 80 or 90% depending on the treatment.  I have to come up with the 10 or 20% required until my out of pocket max is reached, then everything is covered 100%. I'm on disability with a very large company and have great insurance.  My out of pocket is $1500 per year.  Believe it or not , being on SS disability even this amount is hard to come up with every year when your credit cards are maxed out. Last year however, I did have to pay $200 for nuelasta because my medical office would not accept it from my pharmacy coverage as it had to be shipped cold.  It did not matter that I reached my out of pocket max. Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2014 10:20AM ibcmets wrote: Lindsey, I have ibc & idc with bone mets from day 1.  IBC has been known to be very aggressive, that's why chemo is prescribed first.  My onc said if I did not have ibc, he would have put me on hormonals first.  I am also ER+, her2-.  I did tac chemo (taxotere, adriamyacin & cytoxin) for 8 months. After a year of stability, I had a mastectomy.  After chemo I did Femera for 4 years b/4 new bone mets showed up. I then did spot radiation & switched to Aromasin & Affinitor.  I also get Zometa for the bones every other month. Treatment is individualized with each person.  Some treatments work for some & not others so there is a need to switch. Hope your Mom does well with treatment.  Nice that you are looking after her. Terri
Posts.Title: What treatments did you start with? Lindseyc Meadow

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2011 01:32AM ibcmets wrote: Brenna, Glad you checked us out here.  My onc told me the 2-3 years stat as well when I first was diagnosed 6/09.  I'm also ER+, inflammatory with spinal bone mets.  I've done very well on treatment & surgery.  Sorry you are diagnosed at such a young age.  There a quite a few long term bone mets survivors.  Kathy from NY posts yearly for the last 14 years saying she's doing well & enjoying life.  From what I hear, bone mets is the easiest to treat as a chronic condition and not a fatal one.  There are lots of medications for ER+ that will most likely work for you.  I went to the mbcnetwork conference last year for survivors and met many 5/10 & 15 year survivors. Wishing you lots of success with your treatment.  There is so much information here for you.  Please update us on your treatment. Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2015 01:51AM ibcmets wrote: Allyme, I welcome you as well. I know what a shock being stage IV out of the gate when you did not even know you were sick. We are stronger than you think. I was stable for 4 years on Femera & Zometa, now moving onto other drugs. I'm ER+, her2-. It's amazing how far medicine has come along. There has been quite a few I know that live 15 to 20 years with bone mets. Hoping new medical treatments will allow all those with cancer to live long prosperous lives. Terri

Posts.Title: Frozen Shoulder stacey2275 brca1953

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2010 06:28PM ibcmets wrote: Dawn, My frozen shoulder after chemo was so painful.  I could not lift my arm much above my shoulder or hook my bra strap in the back.  I could not open jars, bottles or any slight jerking motion caused severe pain.  I also could not sleep on that side.  I found it best to go to an orthopedic doctor to set you up on therapy.  They specialize in this and can help you get better much quicker than I believe the hospitals can.  I orginally went to the hospital but they did not have enough physical therapists to dedicate a lot of time to me.  I usually ended up sitting waiting for someone to see me for 10 minutes. I have a lot of exercises I have to do at home and had been going in twice a week since May.  I almost have my full range back & now working on strenghtening the arm.  Good Luck with this one.  It takes quite a while to heal. Terri

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2012 06:57PM ibcmets wrote: When I became stage IV from the start, I heard about alkaline water.  I did not want to do MLM and found one much cheaper at Tyent.com.  It's an ionizer and alkalines water & filters out impurities.  The water taste much better than my tap water and due to stage IV, I bit the bullet.  I have bone mets from the start and have been stable for 3 years now. If you don't want to pay the expense, I would suggest drinking bottled spring water like Arrowhead.  I just have this feeling that the minimum chlorine they put in water to make sure no one gets ill could be a problem as well as the hormones added to milk, eggs & meat.  I did not give up meat, but try to eat grass fed or meat with no antibiotics added to it. I wonder why there are so many young people coming down with cancer today.  There are a lot of 20 year olds and younger getting BC.  It would be great if some thorough testing could be done on what goes in our bodies. Terri

I was on it with Aromasin, which I am still on until they decide what is next in line for me. I had 4 good stable years with Femera. I hope you do well on it. Femera caused lots of arthritis problems, but kept me stable for a long time. Terri
Posts.Title: Working full time while taking Afinitor? allyannea Josiesemp

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 11:36AM ibcmets wrote: Mike, I understand your concerns.  I've also been open with my son, he's 16 now.  When diagnosed stage IV out the door 4 years ago, my onc told me I had to get things in place because I was not expected to survive 2 years.  This was in 2009.  Presently, I've been stable for 3 years and doing well.  I would be honest with them and they may be doing their own research as well.  Encourage them to talk to you about any concerns they have and address them.  My son and I had a talk about if I was no longer here, what would happen to him.  I told him that I had savings & insurance policy for him to get him through college and that his Dad would take care of him.  I did not go into detail about my condition, but just answered his concerns.  Some kids may need to talk to someone like a counsler, but my son did not want to do this.  He's very settled now because I told him I would always tell him the truth. You never know who is going to survive for many years or  who will die in the expected time lines so many doctors do not want to speculate, but they do know when the time is near.  At this time your doctors need to be upfront with you to prepare your family.  I do know of a few who have survived stage IV for 17 years, one for 30 years.  This is of course uncommon, but medicine has made great strides in treating this as a chronic condition.  Zometa & femara have worked for me the last 4 years and they are coming out with new drugs all the time. I pray your doctors can get you stable and living well again to see your sons through college and much more. Terri

I was on that for 15 months and had more progression, more spinal bone mets, a rib fracture & a cancerous lymphn node. Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2013 10:51PM ibcmets wrote: 4myangels:  I'm so sorry to hear this.  Do you have any close relatives that would come stay with you until this gets resolved?  6 months after my divorce was final, I found out I had stage IV cancer. States have different laws, but I bet due to the circumstances of you having cancer and not working; he should have to provide medical insurance for the family.  With the new healthcare laws in 2014, pre-existing conditions may be out the door and may not be as expensive as cobra.  At stage IV, I can not imagine a judge making you go out to find work due to your husband wanting a divorce. Maybe you and your husband can look at options outside the box---separtating but staying married or staying together for the family sake.  It was not easy for me on my own with my side of the family living on the other side of the country.  I had to move 3 times due to rent increases while going through chemo. If your husband is reasonable, you should both sit down while you are both calm to discuss how very difficult this is going to be to the kids and both of you financially.   At least he should hold off until financial arrangements can be made possibly like you taking out accelerated benefits on your insurance as a stage IV patient. I pray you don't have to go through this.  Your husband is going to have to deal with this for his kids sake even if you divorce--he's not going to be able to avoid this pain by divorcing you. Financially, I believe he is still responsible for you under these circumstances and it's going to cost him a lot to make this separation financially & emotionally.  I'm praying for you! Terri

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 05:19PM ibcmets wrote: I think we have all been there.  The thing is friends and family are used to taking care of us when we are sick and expect us to be cured, or everything is fine later.  I was overwhelmed with the help & care I received when diagnosed.  My friends & family dropped everything to care for me.  It was quite touching.  A year later and 4 months out of chemo everything is supposed to go back to status quo.  I even feel guilty for asking for help.  I do have a wonderful friend who insists still today to continue going with me to my zometa appointments.  She's gone to all my appts with me and let's me know to call her for any reason.  She is a gem.  It would be so nice not to have to remember that we are stage IV and always will be.  Take each day as it comes and enjoy each day to the fullest.  I walk my little dog on this preserve behind my apartment.  I truly appreciate for one that I can walk my dog and I realize all the beauty given to us to enjoy (creeks with ducks and their baby ducks, turkeys, birds, the beautiful color in flowers & bushes, the warmth from the sun, gentle breezes, etc.)  Sorry to get off track and for getting a little emotional here.  I pray for sunshined days for all of you. Terri

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 09:34PM ibcmets wrote: njwall:  So sorry you are going through all of this.  You need to apply for SSDI--automatic with stage IV.  There is a 6 month waiting period if you've just been diagnosed stage IV.  Ask for a copy of the Patient Resource Cancer Guide for Metastatic Breast Cancer.    Go to patientresource.net or call 816 333-3595.  There are lots of advocacy & assistance groups as well as financial help contacts in the back of this packet. Can you go on Cobra Ins coverage from your prior employer?  You may be able to get a reduced premium for stage IV?  No matter what your age is; after 2 years on SSDI; you will be able to get medicare coverage. I wish you the best with this search.  Do you have a proactive family member to help you with all of this? Terri

Posts.Content: May 1, 2011 09:56PM ibcmets wrote: Those of us who have gone through this know how you feel.  I looked at the picture forum to prepare myself.  I was also a DD and did not want to wake up concave so I opted to start the reconstruction with TE's the same day as the BMX.  It was a 7 hour surgery, but I wanted to eliminate another surgery if I had decided to do it later.  The TE's were as hard as coconuts, but not bad.  I have saline implants now and they are almost as hard as the TE's.  My PS does 2 exchanges.  I'll be swapping out the saline ones for silicone gel ones soon.  I hear they are much softer like natural tissue than the saline.  I will just do the tatoos.  I never liked the nips showing through my clothes anyway. You'll get through this.  One good thing is my boobs are firm and not hanging down to my waist anymore. Terri

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2013 09:40AM ibcmets wrote: Kristy, Very sorry to hear about your diagnosis, especially at such a young age. I have inflammatory bc with spinal bone mets from the start in 6/09. I've done well with treatment. I'm ER+ & did chemo, surgery, Zometa, Femara & recently Aromasin/Afinitor with Radiation for recent new bone mets. I did chemo first due to inflammatory bc. It appears you may be triple positive. You have many options available to you. I got 4years out of Femara. Zometa will keep your bones strong. If you want to see a wonderful movie about the creation of herceptin from Dr. Slamon---rent from Netflix the movie "Living Proof". Herceptin has helped so many women with cancer who are her2+. Harry Connick Jr., Harrison Ford & Bernadette Peters are in the movie. I would also like to let you know of youngsurvival.org . There site is dedicated to those under age 40 with cancer. I hope and believe you will do very well with treatment. Hugs, Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 10:42PM ibcmets wrote: Nil, Opening up as you have may bring you some options and suggestions.  I'm not as young as you, but I'm a Mom with ibc & bone mets since day one in 6/09.  Zometa has done a great job on my bone mets.  I'm also on an AI, Femara that does cause joint pain but I'm doing much better on it now.  I'm sort of in the dumps myself since I just underwent a BMX last week and was really loopey on the pain meds for a week.  It seems never ending sometimes with treatments and all we want to do is get back to normal living.  Nothing seems normal anymore.  I pray your treatments bring you much success and search for those with bone mets who are living great lives with mets.  Kathy's survived 17 or 19 years now.  Search for all the positives you can.  If you are feeling up to it; help where you can at church or in your community as you know what people are going through with this.  Sometimes I think this is why we have this disease so we can be there for those walking in our shoes. Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2016 04:12AM ibcmets wrote: After being on the boards for 6 years with ibc and bone met; I don't believe we know statistics on who will die earlier than another. I've seen many early stage patients die and some late stage survive many years. We also can not predict where our recurrence will travel to. On my 6 th year, I got liver and a brain met that I certainly did not expect because I did so well on Femera. I used to be so logical and follow things as if I would know what would happen. My onc even thought I was one of the lucky ones staying stable for so long with a terminal illness. I also got Afib (heart irregularity) recently making treatment more difficult and life not so much fun. I realize that I will not be one of the stats that survives 15 or 20 years without the grace of God. Still keeping my faith and asking God for his healing and joy. Terri

Posts.Content: May 9, 2011 08:40PM ibcmets wrote: Melania, I had my BMX at the end of Jan.  My PS gave me Percocet (Oxycodoen) for pain.  It totally knocks you out but you have no pain.  I was on this for a week.  I had a lot of pain as well.  After 2 weeks it gets better.  I did not have much pain with the fills.  You may get sharp nerve pain that lasts only a second.  I also thought the BMX was worse than chemo.  It took about a week to get the pathology report back and mine showed residual cancer so I'm glad I had the surgery.  I'm stage IV so they did not take lymph nodes and took all the breast tissue so there is no more tissue to take.  As for driving:  I had to wait until the drains were out, about 14 days.  Hope you continue recovering well. Terri

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2013 02:09AM ibcmets wrote: Sandy, This is such a personal decision.  I for one am so glad I went with treatment as I would not be here today if I had not.  I've read from more than a few on another board who decided not to get treatment until it was too late.  I have also read from those who have exhausted their treatments and just decided for a few months of quality of life instead of going through more painful treatments.  It depends on the person. I'm in a cancer support group and we have had quite a few who have lost their battle with cancer.  Currently, we have one person who has no more options with her medical team or clinical trials due to her condition; she's going into hospice shortly. Not all stage IV cancer patients die in a short time.  Many of us can get many years of a good quality of life.  There is a hospice thread on this board for those who are no longer in treatment. Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 07:04PM ibcmets wrote: Amy, I'm sorry for your diagnosis.  I know stage IV, especially from the start is very difficult to take.  I was diagnosed inflammatory with spinal bone mets from the start in 6/09.  Many health professionals told me I had upto 2years.  The first thing I did was research as much as I could and actually spoke with a couple ladies who had exactly what I had to access my own situation.  I picked out all the positives I could.  I found an article on bone mets online from a doctor that said bone mets is treatable, the same as a chronic condition.  I read about alternative medicine, but knew with ibc that I did not have the time to wait for proper or limited nutrition to work.  I also prayed alot and still do.  This is a fabulous site for comfort & information.  This is going to be a learning process as it's difficult to take in so much info at once.  Research your options given as they come up.  My onc later apologized to me for giving me such a grim outcome as I've done very well on chemo, surgery a year later, Zometa for the bones & Femara daily.  It's about 2.5 years now and I'm doing so much better.  I'm ER/PR+, her2-.  Your biopsy report will list this info for you and will help determine which medication you will have. There are many more stage IV living longer lives.  Sometimes one treatment may take you several years before it does not work for you anymore, and there are quite a few treatments they can transfer you to help you stabilize this disease.  I'm still on the first treatment.  Feel free to ask any questions you may have.  I'd be happy and I'm sure others will be happy to answer questions you have. Best Wishes on your treatment and keep us posted on whats working or not working for you. Hugs, Terri

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 05:20PM ibcmets wrote: I had my BMX Jan 20th, saline implants March 30th & will swap them out to silicone gels sometime this summer.  My PS gets better results with 2 exchanges.  I went from a DD to a C so far and believe it or not, may want to be a bit smaller.  I had sharp nerve pain for a few weeks when the nerves were regenerating, but lasted only a second each time.  I healed very well without any complications.  My PS did a great job, they looked fine in expanders and really great in saline implants; although they feel almost as hard as the expanders.  The gels will soften them up a bit. I guess I'm just glad I had no complications and my breasts are firm now instead of hanging down to my belly.  My tops & dresses fit much better.  I'm one happy camper. Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2010 12:07PM ibcmets wrote: Nicole, Sorry to hear that.  Being in the advanced stage, my onc highly stressed to me to get my affairs in order.  You should get a will done to protect your kids.  If you are happily married, you should make sure your spouse's name is on all your financial accounts for easy access.  If not, if you have a sibling you can entrust these funds to; you can add their name on.  Double check your life insurance policies to see if you have the correct beneficiaries on these.  If you are in a country with Social Security; in the States your x spouse or spouse & children will be able to access funds.  Check your beneficiary on your 401k or IRA. Type a financial statement telling your loved ones everything you have left for them & list names, places & phone numbers for them to access.  I'm mailing mine to my sister.  Give away family heirlooms a head of time to those you intend them to go to.  Get together a photo book for your kids with pictures of the family since they've been born.  I also like the voice suggestion to leave your kids.  Write a journal for your kids of positive things you want them to know & to tell them how important they are to you. Believe me, I'm still in the process of getting all this together.  I'm proactive and a little too organized.  I want to have things in place in case I wont' have the energy or time to do it.  I don't want my family guessing or arguing and in a position to make difficult decisions. Terri

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2014 01:41PM ibcmets wrote: Angie, With stage IV, we experience pain quite a bit and may be from other issues than cancer.  I have bone mets from day one so my onc does PET scans regularly to keep a status on me.  I have Zometa infusions every other month and this has helped strengthen my bones and relieved quite a bit of the back pain for a few years.  Lately, I'm having a lot more back pain & will do another PET scan to see what's up.   When in severe pain, I take Hydorcodone 5mg, sometimes have to take 2.  I can only take heavy pain meds at night because I get sleepy on them & can not drive with them. Hope you'll be feeling better soon--it's no fun to live in pain. Terri

Posts.Content: May 22, 2013 09:46PM ibcmets wrote: Liz, Your work most probably does carry the accelerated death benefit for the group life insurance for you.  Normally it covers up to your yearly sallary, but when hired you may have had the opportunity to pay a small amount more to take out more.  I took out 2X the amount.  I'm in California and I did take out the accelerated death benefit on my work lns policy.  I got 75% and it's not taxable.  They said I could keep the remainder in place for a year, but it would terminate at that time or I could convert it over to a private ins. policy but it was too expensive and had to convert term to whole life. Janis is correct--no double dipping.  Your LTD will deduct what you are getting from SSDI. Terri

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2012 01:03AM ibcmets wrote: Bestbird, I drink alkaline water since I was diagnosed in 6/09.  I did research on it and found a lot of positives for it; some do not believe it does any good.  I started it because I was diagnosed ibc stage IV and was certainly looking for any help I could get.  I also do standard medicine (chemo, surgery & AI & zometa for bone mets).  Did not want to gamble on my diagnosis. The benefits are better tasting water, more oxygen to the water which is supposed to be good for your cells.  I'm sure there are more benefits.    A friend told me about a certain brand and it was too expensive so I found another company with alkaline filters for 1/2 the cost. I hear we are not supposed to advertise here so you can PM me if you want more info on this.  I don't sell this, but would pass on the info because I believe in it.   I personally thinks it's added to my health.  Inspite of stage IV, I've done very well and healed very well from surgery. Terri

Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 10:12PM - edited May 20, 2012 10:14PM by ibcmets Skream, I'm also stage IV out of the gate back in 6/09 (ibc with bone mets).  Can't advise on the house, but there is a financial and insurance forum here.  Being stage IV, you would qualify for SSDI since it looks like you have a work history.  I had to do chemo first because of ibc.  A year after being stable, I did BMX/Recon.  I've been on Zometa for the bones from the start and Femara & Lupron for 2 years. I went on STD, LTD & SSDI & Medicare now since I went through 2 years disability.  My company is now secondary on my medical insurance.  I think most people would make more working if they can handle an 8 hour or more day.  I had so many doctor appts & tests that I went on STD right away. You would need to put "Compassionate Allowance" on top of your SSDI forms as stage IV will bump the handling of your paperwork a top priority. Wishing you well on treatments. Terri

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 02:06AM ibcmets wrote: I was stage IV from the start ibc with spinal bone mets & 3.5cm idc tumor back in 6/09. Due to the ibc, I had to start chemo first; otherwise my onc would have started me  on hormonals.  After chemo, I do Femara & Zometa.  I did Lupron injections because I was pre-menopausal & chose to do Femara.  They just took me off of it as my estrogen levels are lower now that my age is now 54.  I also did BMX/Recon a year after being stable after chemo.  A lot of doctors have different view points on surgery for stage IV and surgeons won't do surgery unless stable unless they have to. Your treatment is not set in stone and individualistic.  Impress upon your onc what you are comfortable with and what is needed. I've been stable since 2010 & doing well.  I've dealt with joint pain & back pain; but otherwise good. Wishing you the best treatment & good results on whatever treatment you choose.  I also became more spiritual & grateful for each and every day the Lord gives me. Terri

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 07:57PM ibcmets wrote: Hi Meena,  I have not met many with inflammatory & bone mets and I see a couple others here.  Sorry you have to join, but there are a few of us in your spot.  I was diagnosed stage IV ibc w/ bone mets in the spine in 6/09.   I also had a 3.5 cm tumor.  My onc did a great job stabilizing me on chemo, zometa & now Femara.  Surgery was not recommended.  I had 8 treatments of cytoxin, taxotere & 4 of adriamyacin.  In 10 months, my scans showed healed bone lesions, tumor gone, just a little ibc inflammation.  I am ER/PR+, her2-.  I used to have scans every 3 months while cancer was very active.  Now, every 6 months.  I'm due for a 6 month pet scan and curious to see what's up on zometa & Femara only.  I'll post when I get the results.  I will say I had some joint pain while starting Femara but 7 months later I don't notice it so much; but I did start walking 2 miles a day with my dog and I believe that has helped a lot.  Keep online with us and ask us any questions you have on your journey.  Best of Luck to you.  Don't fret--there are some met people who have exceeded 5-10 years here.  Our lives are truly in God's care. Hugs, Terri
Posts.Title: Introducing myself meena1 RobinNY

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 01:04PM ibcmets wrote: Same as Scuttlers here. My company actually retired me.  Since I'm on Medicare now, they are still covering the 20% with company ins. (so grateful).  I pay monthly prem for my son & I.  I'm retired with them but the Disability Ins Company still has me send complete medical records every 6 months.  I still have life ins with my company until 2013, at which time I would have to convert it over to a personal policy.  Just got updated records showing my company is allowing 24 months on terminal benefits.  Coolbreeze--just a reminder that SSDI will also give you money for your kids if they are under age 18.  I know the medical insurance is the most important to have at our stage.  Do you have medical ins through your part-time work?  Stage IV is a "compassionate allowance" with SSDI and should move your paperwork through quickly.  There is a 6 month waiting period from diagnosis.  Maybe you can speak with your boss and take off a couple months in order to get the SSDI through as they will also be looking for a last day of work date.  You will still be able later to go back part-time if you make under $800 a month.  Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 08:27PM ibcmets wrote: Thought I'd check with the Feb surgery gals.  I had my BMX/Recon Jan 20th.  This is the first time I've heard from so many how difficult it has been to get help in the hospital.  I was in for 2 nights and had the same problem.  I love my surgeons.  They were fantastic and left instructions from what I heard to check on me every 15 minutes the first night.  I got nauseous from the morphine and do not remember having anyone come in and ask me if I needed anything.  Someone came in several times taking my blood pressure on the wrong arm---my cancer side that was labeled with a pink bracelot for lymphedema.  My IV bags were large enough for the week. I also found I did not have a voice to use the intercom on the bed and could not move my arms to press the buttom anyway.  After they took out the catheter, I had to painfully get out of bed myself to go to the bathroom.  I threw up the liquid diet and it was awful to boot, they gave me very sugary sorbet & popsicles that tasted terrible.  Alarms were going off all the time because the machines did not have new batteries and even then it seemed like more than an hour before the nurse would come in to check the noise.  I did not sleep for 2 nights, even with sleeping pills. I got myself dressed and sat in an uncomfortable chair Sat morning waiting for my sister to pick me up.  About 3 to 4 weeks later, I saw the bill from where the hospital charged $100,000 just for the hospital stay alone for 2 nights.  I thought for sure they must have been understaffed with nurses.  It's nice to know I was not the only one going through this.  I thought for awhile I was just delirious on drugs.   I know my outpatient exchange at the end of this month will go much better. Thank you ladies for giving the new surgery gals a heads up on this. Terri

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 11:31PM ibcmets wrote: Linda,  I hear what you are saying.  There are a lot of things to worry about when you have stage IV--survival,  medical insurance, which treatments to have & what you can afford.  I was just following my company's instructions.  They sent me paperwork explaining the process & I have a case mgr for my LTD.  My company put me on short term disability first for 6 months.  Short term is dependent upon how many years of service you have with the company.  After short term, if I could not go back to my same position; they had me fill out a lot of medical forms & requested scans and such to put me on LTD.  LTD required me with my company to apply for SSDI at the same time as LTD because if you get SSDI, they would not have to cover the 60% salary they would have to pay me, just continue with my medical insurance & benefits.  I'm sure you know stage IV is a compassionate allowance & will be approved with SSDI.  You would have had to work a period of time overall to qualify for payments. I don't see why you would not qualify to be put on your husband's insurance because I don't think they can deny a pre-existing condition but I could be wrong.  I think you can apply for SSDI anytime after the date of your stage IV diagnosis.  There's a 5 month waiting period and some get back pay.  It took me about a month for approval.  Make sure you mark your forms as compassionate allowance because they are processed right away. The best place to get answers would be your HR dept.  Good Luck on your search. Terri

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2016 05:16AM ibcmets wrote: Mrs M, I believe in complimentery medicine along with traditional. I do drink alkaline waterwhen diagnosed stage IV...I knew it could not hurt and was hopeful it would help. Unforunately, 5 years later I've had all types of metastasis. I still drink it because I have the filter. It was worth a try. I've heard of many vegetarians & very healthy people get cancer, so there is no magic bullet. I do take vitamins for energy & D3, no overload and try to stay away from foods that bother my stomach & too much sugar. I could not spend the rest of my life eating gershwin food or nasty diets. As it is now on chemo, I don't have much of an appetite for anything. Terri

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2013 11:28PM ibcmets wrote: Nancy, I think Onc's should be used to confronting this situation with their patients. Mine told me I had about 2 years from the start---it was probably easier b/4 getting to know me to let me know what he thought. He also wanted me to get my affairs in order in case things went bad quickly. He has since apologized and said only God knows when someone's life is going to end because I've done very well on all the treatment he gave me. I'm 4.5 years out now. If treatments are working & there's many in the pipeline; we most likely can be treated as a chronic condition. I feel grateful that I'm monitored quite well with blood work & scans to see for myself how I'm doing. I think if the time comes when nothing is working; your onc will have to talk to you & and your family about what to expect in the near future. Terri

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2011 02:18PM ibcmets wrote: Leah, I'm stunned that your BS told you this.  I agree with Mindfulness.  Many onc's are recommending surgery at stage IV to get rid of the primary.  I believe the studies are showing longer survival time and QOL.  My onc recommended surgery to me after I was stable for a year from ibc w/ bone mets.  This is the first time in 2 years that my Pet scans came out clean, 6 months after surgery.  My bone mets show healed at this time. I truly believe there is a great benefit for surgery.  I had bi-lateral with reconstruction and I'm doing well.  The pathology report from surgery showed cancer in the tissue that was taken off.  Six months later, no cancer.  After surgery, your BS will have to pass you off for care to your onc & PS, so you will not have to see her again. Push for the surgery.  Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2011 05:32PM ibcmets wrote: Joy, Many of us have different experiences even with the same treatment plan.  My Mom did not do well on chemo and I did very well.  The worst for me was losing all my hair, runny eyes and fatigue.  Whether we are stage IV or not; we go through a lot of the same treatments.  I'm on Femara (AI) and had joint pain for awhile but I got used to the medication and don't have any more pain or discomfort.  Calling a Support organization would be the best recommendation for her.  There are quite a few of us living fairly normal lives, seeing our kids grow up and appreciating what we have each day.  No one is guaranteed another day. I hope your friend's depression can be resolved and she can make a good decision with her doctors.  Some make a decision to not have anymore treatment after they have been through so much; but they gave it a try.    I hope your friend does too.   You never know---she can be here with minimal discomfort for 5-10-15 or 20 years.  Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 24, 2016 03:28PM ibcmets wrote: CM, With stage IV, they usually radiate bone mets in spine only when in pain or getting too close to spinal cord. I did targeted radiation on my spine several times and have no pain today. It was about 10 days of radiation just to the area. Depending on where mets are, your Mom may be tired and have heartburn or some pain lasting for about 2 weeks. I'm just about 7 years out and we still only treat the bone mets if mobility is compromised or having a lot of back pain. I started ER+ and now triple negative. I've already exhaused hormonals so I'm back on chemo for other cancers I have. I think your Mom will do fine. Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2014 08:17PM ibcmets wrote: Benjnate, I understand what you are saying.  I was diagnosed ibc with bone mets in 6/09.  The pain I had was only from the meds & radiation.  That's when my back started hurting but the Zometa worked wonders in resolving the pain & strengthening the bones.  I've often heard that cancer does not hurt, probably why some of us are already a later stage when diagnosed. I get all my PET scans & read them b/4 speaking with my onc so I know what questions to ask.  I was pretty upset at the last one because a new radiologist read it and listed everything on it from 6/09 and even put I had lung lesions that I never knew about.  Apparently my onc said it proved the new medication A/A was working & I did not have to bother with the rest.  I trust my onc & let it go. It seems so strange to be told we do not have long to live when we feel ok, just a little tired.  My onc said he would put me through all the AI's b/4 going back to chemo.  I'm on my 2nd AI.  I know there are a lot more meds out there for you.  Did he talk about faslodex?  My onc has a patient stable on Faslodex for 6 years.  Each person is different.   Hoping your treatment works for a very long time. Terri

We all try to plan how long we will be on disability, whether we will be able to keep some kind of medical insurance, whether we will be terminated from work if we choose to go back full-time and can not handle it.  I worry about the future and it's been difficult making decisions today when I don't know what to expect.  With metastatic; is it possible to be stable for more than 2,5 10 years?  I sure would appreciate any input you have on this. Posts.Content: Apr 29, 2013 03:19PM ibcmets wrote: I've always had a hard time losing weight and now depleting my estrogen I had gained 25 lbs over the last 2 years.  I just had to get the weight off.  I've always hated low carb diets but I'm on a Jumpstart program which is low carb and I've lost 16 lbs in the last 6 weeks.  I average about 2 lbs loss a week.  The plan is easy and I just check off boxes for the day of food I eat, no counting calories.  I get 4 carbs a day, 2 small fruit & 2 veggies plus all the salad I want.  I also check off 12 oz of protien a day and lots of water. It's been doable for me and I've given myself a year to get off all the weight.  Still need to lose about 45 lbs.  I use to overload on carbs.  You'll find if you limit carbs, you won't be hungry or craving anything (although you may be a bit fatigued). Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2016 08:46AM ibcmets wrote: DLS23, I hear many doctors go for more agressive treatment with early stage to go for a cure, which options are off the table with stage IV. I did not get my bone mets biopisied, it was pretty obvious what they were and treatment has worked well with them. I did bi-lateral a year after chemo because my breast was still inflamed and highly recommended having inflammatory bc. Chemo is most likely first for inflammatory because it's like a nesting of cancer.. Many doctors may like to try hormomals first, then chemo and radiation.I have heard of women refusing one or the other for whatever reason. Do as much research as possible. Terri

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2012 01:08PM ibcmets wrote: I'm a dog lover as well.  It's very sad to hear about letting go of a beloved pet.  As others stated, I feel you will know when your dog is in a lot of pain, you can see it in their eyes and know when they stop eating, running around & wagging their tails.  Just try to make sure you do not prolong their suffering to keep them here.  A neighbor of mine was heartsick recently to put her dog down.  The dog could not walk the stairs anymore to their apt.  On a lighter note, my little papion mix (Lucky) is a very spoiled girl.  She got a bee sting while walking,so my son & I wrapped one of those elastic arm bands I get from chemo treatments around her front paw.  We babied her and she walked around limping for a couple of days.  I think she was milking the attention as the next day she was chasing after other dogs like there was no problem.  Unless she's injured, she won't let us touch her paws. Terri

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2011 10:48PM ibcmets wrote: Kimbo, I have bone mets (spinal & femur) from the start in 6/09.  I've been on Zometa since then.  It's worked very well and has healed my lesions.  They show up as healed lesions on my scans.  I have Pet scans done every 6 months.  So far, so good.  I'm also on Femara & Lupron.  Have not had to change any medications yet.  I also hear if it stays in the bones; we have a fairly good chance of living with a chronic condition for a long time.  Best Wishes on your treatment. Terri
Posts.Title: bone mets klewandowski lulubee

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2011 05:14PM ibcmets wrote: thats-life, I thought anyone with bone mets would be put on Zometa or Xgeva.  I started this the same week I did chemo in 6/09.  I did have a 3.5 cm tumor & inflammatory which chemo got under control.  Not completely sure; but I feel my bone mets show healed due to the Zometa.  I was told I would always be on this...they may space it out after a few years to reduce the chance of getting ONJ.  So far it's working. Terri

Posts.Content: Aug 7, 2010 08:17PM ibcmets wrote: Thank you so much ladies for responding so quickly.  I've always been a worry wart & a planner.  I know there's a thread listing stage IV survivors and how long---but I was wondering even if I was a long term survivor; how many different times I would have to start chemo treatments all over again to stay stable.  Also, I'm on LTD & SSDI but my company reviews LTD every 6 months.  They may not extend my LTD being stable now even if I could not perform my job fulltime.  They are covering my medical right now and I would have no insurance until 2 years out on SSDI for medicare. I won't have my scans done again until after the date LTD determines my eligibility. You would think I would just be ecstatic that I was stable for now.  Bonnie, Elaine & Cat:  thank you for your response. I so much appreciate all of you for sharing your struggles & offering information.  A lot of answers are not found anywhere but from those who have gone through the same thing.  I appreciate all of you. Thanks, Terri

Posts.Title: Worried about a PET scan raysnbucs ibcmets

Posts.Content: Oct 7, 2011 11:50AM ibcmets wrote: Lilredpony, Sorry about your sudden stage IV diagnosis.  We all know how scary that is.  I also was diagnosed stage IV from the start with spinal bone mets in 6/09.  I'm doing well.  I had a combo of taxotere, adriamyacin & cytoxin for 8 months.  It slowly reduced the cancer & my 3.5 cm tumor.  I'm also on monthly Zometa for the bone mets which I've done really well with.  I have Pet scans every 6 months now to check status.  After chemo, they put me on Femara (an AI) for ER/PR+ status. You can check with many long term survivors  at  www.mbcnetwork.org.   It is possible to be treated as a chronic condition for many years with this disease.  Best wishes on your treatment. Terri
Posts.Title: Im a newby and scared lilredpony DivineMrsM

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2012 02:15AM ibcmets wrote: Soleil, Sorry about your progression.  I hope your onc comes up with a successful plan to get you stable again soon. Terri
Posts.Title: scans not good ....progression. Guess I have to to plan Q soleil505 vickib

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2014 08:03PM ibcmets wrote: Sh, Sorry to hear of your Mom's progression.  I had stage IV with spinal bone mets from day 1 in 6/09.  I'm doing well.  I've been on Zometa for 4.5 years now which has eliminated most back pain & made my bones stronger.  I switched from Femara recently to Aromoasin/ Afinitor.  I got 4 years out of Femara & just did radiation for a spot on my spine.  My radiologist says I have very little cancer in my body.  I will always be in some kind of treatment but they are keeping me stable.  There are quite a few treatments for ER+ patients.  We can go through all of these b/4 going back on chemo.  Hope your Mom does well with her treatments.  Blessing for the new year! Terri

Posts.Title: Just when I thought things were getting better... konakat Marple

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2012 09:39PM ibcmets wrote: Keephealth, Sorry about your progression to bone mets.  Having any metastasis is scary but bone mets can be treated as a chronic condition.  I also was diagnosed stage IV ibc with bone mets from the start in 6/09.  Due to inflammatory bc, chemo was  the starting treatment.  I've been on Femara, Lupron & Zometa for almost 2.5 years.  Femara gave me a lot of joint pain & stiffness for about 6 months, but doable now.  Lupron suppresses the estrogen (ER/PR+, her2-).  I do take Glucosamine & chondrotin to help with joint pain & it seems to work for me.  I get scans once every 6 months to check status & have been clean for almost 2 years.  Zometa has been a wonder drug for me so far with the bone mets.  Many onc's are using Xgeva shots now...but my onc is waiting as the Zometa does such a wonderful job. This is a great site to ask questions.  Best Wishes on your treatment. Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2012 01:51AM - edited Jan 23, 2012 01:52AM by ibcmets Most likely, you'll have expanders placed at time of bmx and get saline fills every 2 weeks after recovering from BMX.  Many PS's don't go  by size but how you look.  As you get the fills, you should be able to tell if that is the size you want to be and then they can schedule the exchange surgery to replace expanders with implants.  I had both implants a few months apart. The saline ones were hard but you may be able to go bigger in these.  The silicone gels are softer, more like real tissue but will be wider.  I was a DD and wanted to go smaller but feel I can still fit in a D cup because the of width. However, I'm able to just wear camisoles now.  I'm very happy with the gels.  Ask your PS about the recommended fit size.  I believe the gels only go to 800cc's, but you can get them as high profiles which will give you a bit more upfront. Whippetmom is the expert at size.  Give her your measurements and she can make a suggestion for you. Terri

Posts.Content: ibcmets wrote: Thought I would start the Jan 2011 thread.  I'm scheduled for a bi-lateral mastectomy with reproduction on Jan 20th.  Since I'm going down from a DD to a B; I was told I would be in expansions for about a month.  My Plastic Surgeon likes to exchange with saline for a better fit and than do a gel extension. Thank you to all who have posted with suggestions.  Got my wedge lift from bed bath & beyond since I don't have a reclining chair, also some extra pillows.    A lady from inspire.com sent me a pillow she makes to make the seat belts more comfortable when you're in the car.  She also has beautiful quilts.  Her site is breastcancerdiy.com (diy is for do it yourself).  I also liked the tips for the drain pockets on this site. Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 02:57PM ibcmets wrote: I found that the foam wedge on my bed is working great for sleep.  I could not get up from the bed in the hospital, but I can from home.  I take pain meds and antibiotics every 6 hours and I've been sleeping well at home.  Remember to take something in your stomach about 15 minutes b/4 taking the meds.  I have to wake myself up to take them & I've  been getting yogurt down.  It helps a lot so you don't get an upset stomach.  This is the 3rd day after surgery and I'm itching quite a bit.  My sister has been wonderful taking care of me.  My plastic surgeon was supposed to go out of town right after my surgery; but decided to stick around for me.  I have the best doctors.  Good Luck to the girls this week on surgery.  If you are doing reconstruction; you may be hurting a bit after so take your meds. Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 01:06AM ibcmets wrote: Christine, Thanks for letting me know about your recovery.  I must have misunderstood.  I thought my doctors told me take the oxycodone every 6 hours until they told me not to.  I was so messed up all week.  I only stayed up a couple hours at a time and could not keep my eyes open.  I even set my alarm to make the 6 hours.  I had trouble with being nausesous when I finally went for a very short car ride to pick up meds.  I also threw up in the ps first office visit.  He took me off the oxycodone and antibiotics which made me itch.  By the end of the eveving, I was feeling much better and was able to stay up much longer.  I'm supposed to get the drains out Monday and the PS says I'm healing wonderfully.  The nurses said this was the worst of it and the expansions will go much smoother. *Double check with your doctors about your pain meds.  I did not go home with the pump because I was also throwing up in the hospital on the morphine pump.  Just trying to get my internal clock back to normal.  Hope everyone is fairing better than I was. Terri

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 02:26PM - edited Mar 12, 2014 02:29PM by ibcmets Kay, A lot depends on who your employer is.  I was with a large company with good benefits.  I had short & long term disablility.   When I was diagnosed stage IV from the start & most of my days were doctors appts & tests, I took short term for 6 months and had to go on long term after.  With my company , I had to apply for SSDI while going on LTD.  They paid my health insurance, I paid the premiums which were larger than when employed but not over $200 a month for both my son & myself.  After 2years on SSDI, I applied for Medicare & my company supplemented medicare as secondary insurance for myself & still kept my son's health insurance in force.  LTD pays 65% or can pay 75% if you ask for it at the time of hiring for some companies but payments are deducted from SSDI.  I could not collect both at same time.  I hear some can.  Also, yearly complete medical papers are requested each year to stay on LTD and they don't go  by SSDI standards for approval.  If you could not go back to your job and company was not able to place you in job that accomadated your disablility, they would keep you on LTD. My medicare premiums are taken out of my SSDI checks b/4 receiving payment ($115 a month).  Medicare is primary & sends claims to Untited Healthcare (my 2ndry ins).  I pay 10%.  Each year my out of pocket goes up & my deductible is about $500 but much cheaper than many insurance companies. Companies do not have to offer medical insurance to those on LTD.  I believe you can get cobra until medicare kicks in, but it's more expensive.   You may be able to qualify for Obamacare with reduced premiums due to disability and no pre-existing conditions exist anymore, which is good.  After 5 years on disability, my company is outsourcing the insurance to retired employees to a private obamacare policy next year.  I have no idea about the coverage yet.  They put me on the retired list when I could not go back to work. The best place to ask these questions is with your company's benefits dept as we all work for different companies. Terri
Posts.Title: Disability Question kayrnic redwolf8812

Posts.Content: Jan 3, 2013 07:20PM ibcmets wrote: TexasRose, Women are generally caregivers of their families.  I think we feel responsible for family members.  Since I got cancer, I feel like my responsibility is to myself and my son.  I can say no without feeling guilty to invitations, or asked to get involved with anything that would be too much for me.  I prioritize my life better than I did before. Adults have to make their own decisions and from past experiences in my own family, I realize that we can enable someone to continue making bad choices by offering too much help.  My brother-in-law finally got his act together from drug abuse when he no longer had his brothers to lean on.  He's a great father and provider now and keeps close to his church.  My own brother is a different story and really has not changed his life or drug abuse much. A friend of mine told me about a website at www.pointofreturn.com   They slowly ween people off of drugs with little side effects by reducing the dosage until they are not using at all.  It worked really well for his daughter. Terri

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2011 11:39PM ibcmets wrote: Priscilla, I have stage IV from the start, ibc with bone mets 6/09.  Since my scans have shown "not metabolically active" bone mets; my onc had me do a BMX.  I had been stable for a year so he thought it was a good time to do it.  I'm glad I had the BMX as my pathology report after surgery showed micro cancer in the breast that did not show up on scans.  6 months after surgery, my scans were clean showing bone met lesions that were not active. There is a difference of opinion among doctors on doing surgery on stage IV patients; but more doctors are going with the surgery as long as the patient is stable.  Glad your treatment is working. Terri

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2011 07:08PM ibcmets wrote: Tammie, You may find some diet info on the alternative thread.  Eating healthy will help your immune system & help your body recover from traditional medications & treatment needed. Personally, I gave up artificial sweetners & soda.  I try to juice a bit with apples & carrots to get more vitamins & enzymes.  I also drink alkaline water from an alkaline filter.  I don't follow an alkaline diet; but drink the water.  It's supposed to bring more oxygen to your body to help you heal.  I also drink organic milk because I don't want the hormones that they add to pasterized milk as well as the hormones with beef.  I eat chicken, fish, eggs, veggies, fruit & whole grains.  I saw the DVD movie "Food, Inc." that gave a lot of information about how our food is produced here in the states and made some changes. Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 03:12PM ibcmets wrote: Patty, As a stage IV survivor from the get go in 6/09, I'd like to give you positive support.  It's very scary being diagnosed stage IV.  I found I can handle the treatments and I've been doing well for almost 5 years now.  I've got bone mets and find I may be able to treat this for a long time.  I also have a son who is also very quiet.  He's 16 now and having him see me do so well has calmed his fears.  He still does not want to go to any appts. with me but trusts that I will tell him of any changes in my condition.  As long as I tell him, he can deal with it.  I try to put a positive spin on things.  Because of my condition, I can be there with him for any school & athletic events & pick him up every day from school.  I get to spend more time with him, which I'm so grateful for.  Hoping you respond very well to treatments and continue to be active & healthy for your kids & husband. Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2010 03:48PM ibcmets wrote: I was a recipient of a grant from Komen to attend the IND metastatic conference.  I'm very appreciative of this gift.  I think we should work with these large bc organizations as they have been so successful at fund raising and I'm also very happy that they are now working for a cure instead of awareness. I think awareness had to come first, which they have done a wonderful job and it makes it easier for us as metastatic survivors and inflammatory patients to be recognized in the bc community by working with them.  I agree, we should worry about where the money is going to; not where it comes from. Terri
Posts.Title: Balanced view of Komen EnglishMajor ibcmets

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 02:42PM ibcmets wrote: Rosevalley, I feel very lucky to have a great oncologist.  My biopsy showed invasive idc as well as ibc.  He ran me through all tests like PET scans, bone scans, MRI & brain MRI and all confirmed diagnosis so even though I did not have pain; I was certain of what my diagnosis was from the start.  I believe it makes it a lot easier for doctors to treat patients if they run all the test. There are protocals in place for cancer diagnosis and it's very nice to be on the same page and know you are getting the best of care. Terri

Posts.Content: ibcmets wrote: Thought I would start the Jan 2011 thread.  I'm scheduled for a bi-lateral mastectomy with reproduction on Jan 20th.  Since I'm going down from a DD to a B; I was told I would be in expansions for about a month.  My Plastic Surgeon likes to exchange with saline for a better fit and than do a gel extension. Thank you to all who have posted with suggestions.  Got my wedge lift from bed bath & beyond since I don't have a reclining chair, also some extra pillows.    A lady from inspire.com sent me a pillow she makes to make the seat belts more comfortable when you're in the car.  She also has beautiful quilts.  Her site is breastcancerdiy.com (diy is for do it yourself).  I also liked the tips for the drain pockets on this site. Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 01:47PM ibcmets wrote: I'm also more tired and need naps.  My family left after 2 weeks after surgery. It was so nice to have my sister & niece here to do everything.  Now, I have to set my alarm to get up at 7:30 to take my son to school & pick him up and take him to all his baseball practices.  I rest during the day.  I had chemo last year and was a lot more tired than I am now, but healing does take time. Barbara:  After 3 weeks, I'm just starting to try to sleep on my side.  One side has too much tissue so I can not use that side, but the other seems ok.  Right after drains come out is not a good time to sleep on sides as it will increase leakage from drain areas until it scabs over.  It's a good thing I'm not married, my bed is still packed with pillows & a  sponge wedge I keep close to my body for sleep.  This wedge may help support your back a bit so you can try to sleep on one side.  Still working it out myself.  Sometimes I take benadryl to help me sleep. Terri

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2012 12:57PM ibcmets wrote: Spamgirl, Please re-read the last 2 paragraphs of Sophie's response.  Guilt is not something you should be harboring here.  Cancer is not something you created to destroy your family.  It happened to you just like it happened to each of us.   It certainly is a heads-up for us to prepare for our families when we are gone, but you have done this....your insurance will take care of things so you won't have to worry about your family.  If you wanted to relieve some debt now and make it easier to get by and pay medical expenses and such, you can apply for "accelerated death benefits" from your insurance.  Many policies will give 75-80% of benefits payable now if signed by your onc that you have limited time left.  It needs to be written in your policy but very well may be an option for you. My pt is do not feel guilty. Terri

Posts.Content: Oct 9, 2012 12:31PM ibcmets wrote: Annie, Very sorry to hear about your Mom's diagnosis.  Zometa & Tamoxifen may help her.  I was stage IV from the start with bone mets and have been on Zometa & Femara for 3 years now.  I've been stable on this so far.  I did chemo to start with and  a year later surgery.  You could get a 2nd opinion but she needs to be strong enough to go through chemo again as it brings down the immune system.  Personally, I would not have her continue radiation as it is palliative in stage IV. Saying prayers for you and your Mom. Terri

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2011 06:42PM ibcmets wrote: Just got home today from BMX/Recon.  I went in Thurs for 6 hours for surgery.  I have to say I was miserable and in a lot of pain from recontruction for 2 days.  I was so glad they let me go home today.  I feel much better. I think the Morpine made me throw up and I felt so bruised from the reconstruction.  Hopefully, I won't be in this much pain anymore.  I'm on oxycodone for pain and I'm itching a bit, but it is taking care of the pain.   Glad to just be out of bed.  Wishing everyone the best for this week's surgery. Terri

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 08:45PM ibcmets wrote: Cling, I'm 2 weed out of bi-lateral mastectomy/Recon.  Accept all the help you can get the first 2 weeks.  I was on heavy meds the first week out of surgery and all I could do was sleep.  It took about 4 days to get most of my arm movements back.  In the hospital, I could not move them at all.  Be careful with friends staying too long as you will be tired.  My sister and niece did everything for me.  Best Wishes on your recovery. Terri
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 05:33PM ibcmets wrote: Thought I would add some bra support help after mastectomy.  I'm 2 weeks out and wore an Amoena sports bra with front closure.  The store told me to get a tight fit, and it's been uncomfortable.  I feel really tight even before any fills and the elastic underneath itches me. I went to Kohls and got some nice Jockey seamless removable cup sports bras (2 for $32) and some  lighter weight colored sports bras without the heavy elastic band.  I also got some soft loose camis for $16.  What a difference.  I don't itch and if you are still draining fluids after the drains are removed, you can easily fit a folded washcloth under your armpit to catch any fluid. You can even put in some pads in the removable cup sports bras.   I think I spent less than 1/2 the cost for all 6 garmets than what I paid for 2 at a mastectomy store. Glad all of you are doing well after surgery.  Almost time to add our names to the expansion section. Have a great weekend. Terri

Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 01:39PM - edited Mar 9, 2011 01:42PM by ibcmets Hi AnaM, We seemed to have  had surgery together.  As I posted, I was filled quite a bit in surgery and only had 2 fills and have a date for expansion on March 30th.  The TE's really don't bother me anymore and look like natural breasts but feel like turtle shells. Best Wishes on Chemo on the 10th.  I had 8 months of Taxotere & Cytoxan.  They gave me Emmed tablets to counter act nauseousness that worked really well.  Some side effects I had were bloody nose, teary eyes.  I took benadryl which cleared up some of the moisture in my eyes and helped with the nose bleeds a bit.  I was very fatigued and this will take time to get better.  I also had a gall stone 2cm that started acting up right after chemo.  Once they put me on Prilosec, I was fine.  Walking a bit will help with your energy levels.  Best to you on the chemo.  Let us know how it's going and if you need any support through this. Terri
Posts.Title: January 2011 Mastectomy ibcmets SuebeeBC

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2011 10:25PM ibcmets wrote: Cindy, I had mine on the same day.  I'm pretty tight on one side.  I did have some muscle tightness the first month like muscle spasms but no longer.  I have a port as well, but it was put in over a year ago for chemo.  They want me to keep it just in case it's needed since I don't have any problems with it.  Doing my exchange March 30th.  Best to you with treatment. Terri

Terri

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2014 04:54PM ibcmets wrote: Mary-Lou, Thank you for your post. I find myself in the same position. Femera lasted me 4years. This past year I've been on Aromasin & Affinitor which has not produced one good scan all year. My last PET scan in Dec was the worst. I now have liver mets, a new bone met, a fractured rib & my lymph node that was radiated is now twice the size. My doc is on 3 weeks vacation. I hear I may be doing a liver biopsy soon to see if my ER status has changed. I'll update once I find out what they will put me on next. I wish you successful treatments. It's nice to know of so many doing well with getting rid of those liver mets. Terri
